Module com.example.project3
Package com.example.project3

Class Date

java.lang.Object
com.example.project3.Date
public class Date
extends java.lang.Object
The Date class takes in a String in the format "mm/dd/yyyy" and creates a Date * object with attributes month, day, and year, or can do so by default is we are * using the current calendar date. It also can compare two Date objects * to one another to check for equality, return the Date in a toString format, * and check if the Date is a valid given date while accounting for leap year variability.
Author:
Sebastian Carrasco, Rachael Chin

    • isValid

      public boolean isValid()
      Checks to see if a date is valid
      Returns:
      a true value/boolean if the date is valid, false if it is not

    • isLeapYear

      private boolean isLeapYear​(int year)
      isLeapYear will check to see if a year is a leap year
      Parameters:
      year - is the integer representation of the year
      Returns:
      a boolean or true value if it is a leap year, and false if it is not

    • compareTo

      public int compareTo​(Date date)
      The compareTo method will compare the current date with a given date to see if it's a previous date, future date, or the same date
      Parameters:
      date - the object representation of the date
      Returns:
      an integer to see if the given year, month or date is less than, greater than, or equal to current year, month, or date and will return either -1, 1, or 0 accordingly

    • toString

      public java.lang.String toString()
      The toString method will return a string representation of the object
      Overrides:
      toString in class java.lang.Object
      Returns:
      a String literal for the month, day, and year in the formal of mm/dd/yyyy
